questions.text: An elderly man is being evaluated for exertional dyspnea, cough, and weight loss. His chest CT is given below. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows emphysematous lungs, with reduced parenchymal markings and focal areas of low attenuation. This represents the emphysematous destruction of the lung, indicative of hyperinflation.

Radiographic studies in COPD show:

  • Emphysematous bullae
  • A paucity of parenchymal markings
  • Hyperlucency suggests the presence of emphysema
  • Increased lung volumes and flattening of the diaphragm suggest hyperinflation

Option B: Atypical pneumonia shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities.

Option C: Calcified granulomas are seen as dense, bright nodules.

Option D: Interstitial fibrosis shows a honeycomb pattern of the lung parenchyma as shown below.

questions.text: A 3-month-old male child was brought with a history of fever and respiratory distress. Suspecting pneumonia, a chest X-ray was ordered. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows pneumatoceles (air-filled cysts within lung parenchyma), which most commonly occur in pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus may be primary or secondary (after a viral infection such as influenza).

Clinical features include high fever, abdominal pain, dyspnoea, and tachycardia. S. aureus often causes necrotizing pneumonitis that may be associated with complications like early development of empyema, pneumatocele, pyopneumothorax, and bronchopleural fistulas.

Pneumatocoele can also be caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, E. coli, group A streptococci, Klebsiella pneumoniae, etc. However, Staphylococcus aureus is most commonly implicated.

questions.text: Identify the imaging procedure shown below.
questions.solution:
The imaging procedure shown above is mediolateral oblique mammography.

The mammogram is an X-ray picture of the breast. The anode in the X-ray tube is made up of molybdenum. The X-ray film used is single-sided coated films.

Views used are:

  • Craniocaudal
  • Mediolateral oblique

The father of mammography is Robert Egan.

Uses of the mammogram:

  • Routine screening for DCIS.
  • The most important sign of malignancy in mammogram is clustered micro calcification (more than 5 particles in 1 cm², 3 particles of less than 0.5 mm size)

The image below shows different types of calcifications.

The image below shows MRI scans.

The image below shows a CT scan.

The image below shows a USG.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as A in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution: The structure marked as "A" in the CT Thorax is the ascending aorta.

questions.text: A neonate is being evaluated for urinary abnormalities. Ultrasonography reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The given image shows a dilated proximal urethra and associated thick-walled distended bladder on ultrasound that resembles a keyhole. This keyhole sign is seen in the presence of posterior urethral valves.

questions.text: A child with recurrent UTIs is suspected to have a congenital renal anomaly. The following picture is seen on IV urography. Based on these findings, which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a right-sided fish hook or S-shaped ureter. It describes the appearance of a retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC.

Circumcaval or retrocaval ureter is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). It is due to abnormal development of the right supracardinal system. There is a persistent right posterior cardinal vein that ends up passing in front of the ureter. The anomaly always occurs on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC.

Note: Bilateral fishhook or J-shaped or hockey stick ureters describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH).

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is being evaluated for a change in bowel habits associated with abdominal discomfort. A barium enema study was done and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium study showing apple core sign is suggestive of carcinoma colon.

Apple core sign/napkin ring sign describes a short segment of irregular circumferential stricture involving the large bowel. It has shouldered margins resembling an apple core. The appearance is classically described on contrast enema studies and is almost always due to a stenosing annular colon carcinoma.

questions.text: All of the following could be the cause of the following X-ray finding except:
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows air under the diaphragm which is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. Acute intestinal obstruction does not cause pneumoperitoneum.

Causes of pneumoperitoneum include:

  • Bowel perforation
    • Peptic ulcer
    • Ischemic bowel
    • Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Small bowel perforation
    • Trauma
    • Penetrating injuries
  • Causes other than perforation are:
    • Chilaiditi syndrome - the intestine is seen between the liver and diaphragm giving a false impression of free air
    • Sub-phrenic abscess
    • Postoperatively, air may be present in the abdomen for up to 7 days

An intestinal obstruction would show multiple dilated loops on X-ray with possible air-fluid levels. Only when the obstruction becomes severe and there is a perforation, pneumoperitoneum occurs.

The image given below is an abdominal radiograph showing multiple dilated loops with air-fluid levels suggestive of intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the casualty with a severe headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. There is no history of trauma. CT head is shown below. What is the most common cause for his presentation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of non-traumatic subarachnoid haemorrhage. The most common cause for this condition is the rupture of a berry aneurysm, also known as a saccular aneurysm.

CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.

Most unruptured intracranial aneurysms are completely asymptomatic. Prodromal symptoms occasionally suggest the site of the enlarging unruptured aneurysm. For example, cranial nerve III palsy with loss of ipsilateral light reflex and focal pain above or behind the eye suggests an expanding aneurysm at the junction of the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid artery.

Ruptured aneurysms cause an excruciating thunderclap headache followed by a transient loss of consciousness.

Non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice for SAH. LP shows xanthochromatic CSF.

Treatment involves clipping or coiling the aneurysm to eliminate the risk of rebleeding.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: Identify the imaging and structure marked as A.
questions.solution:
The image depicts an MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography) and the structure marked as A is the common bile duct.

MRCP is a non-invasive test showing a heavy T2 weighted image. Endoscope or contrast medium is not used as bile itself serves as a contrast medium.

The image given below shows ERCP.

questions.text: The chest x-ray of a child who presented with progressive breathlessness is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a boot-shaped heart which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). It shows an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy and a concave pulmonary arterial segment.

 TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart condition and has four characteristic components:

  • Ventricular septal defect 
  • Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (pulmonary stenosis)
  • Overriding aorta
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (late feature)

Other radiographic features seen in TOF are:

  • Pulmonary oligaemia (due to pulmonary stenosis)
  • Normal size heart without heart failure 
  • Right-sided aortic arch (in 25% cases)

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in cardiology

Sign
Condition
Flask shaped/ Pear shaped/ Leather bottle shaped/ Money-bag shaped heart
Pericardial effusion
Boot shaped heart/ Coeur-en-sabot
Fallot’s tetralogy
Gooseneck sign
Endocardial cushion defects
Box-shaped heart
Ebstein's anomaly
Jug handle appearance
Primary pulmonary artery hypertension
“3” like appearance of the aorta
Coarctation of aorta
Egg on string appearance
Transposition of great vessels
Egg in cup appearance, Pericardial calcification
Constrictive pericarditis
Snowman’s heart, Cottage loaf appearance, Figure of Eight appearance
Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation
Scimitar sign
Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return
Calcification in the heart wall
Carcinoid syndrome
Calcification of ascending aorta
Atherosclerosis, Syphilis
Hilar dance on fluoroscopy
Atrial septal defect
Batwing appearance
Pulmonary edema
Pruned tree appearance of the pulmonary vasculature
Pulmonary artery hypertension

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida has come for an antenatal ultrasound examination. The sonographic image appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the lemon sign, which is seen in spina bifida.

Spina bifida is the common open neural tube defect associated with hydrocephalus and Arnold-Chiari II malformation. It is the most common open neural tube disorder.

Spina bifida is characterized by a cleft in the vertebral column with a corresponding defect in the skin so that the meninges and spinal cord are exposed.

The lemon sign is related to changes in the configuration of the fetal frontal bone that loses convexity, becoming concave or linear at ultrasonography, and can be found during the first six months of gestation.

The banana sign is another sign that is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari II. There is herniation of the brainstem and cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, with the cerebellum surrounding the brainstem with a curved shape of a banana.

Other options:

Option B: Anencephaly is characterized by an open defect in the calvaria and skin, such that the cranial neural tube is exposed. It is a severe defect and is not compatible with survival. Frog eye sign is seen in USG. Prominent orbits (arrows) and an absence of cerebral tissue more cranially are seen.

Option C: Holoprosencephaly is a rare congenital brain malformation resulting from incomplete separation of the two hemispheres. On antenatal ultrasound there may be also evidence of polyhydramnios and ultrasound may also show a snake under the skull sign.

Option D: Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. Given below is an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix).

questions.text: A 15 year old patient with history of spinal tuberculosis was brought to the hospital with low grade fever, dull backache and persistent flexion of hip joint. Hip joint motion was limited and painful. Identify the muscle affected in the CT image.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with low-grade fever, dull backache, and persistent flexion of the hip joint with a history of spinal tuberculosis is suggestive of psoas abscess involving the psoas muscle, marked 2 in the given image. CT scan shows a mass in the psoas muscle lateral to the vertebral column which is diagnostic of the same.

Psoas abscess occurs due to a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment. The compartment is retroperitoneal and hence, the abscess is also called a retroperitoneal abscess. The compartment contains iliacus and iliopsoas muscles. The psoas compartment muscles lie in close proximity to major abdominal organs and is richly supplied by iliolumbar, external iliac and common femoral arteries. Owing to these reasons, there is hematogenous spread of infections like tuberculosis leading to abscess.

Clinical presentation is with back pain, fever, and lassitude. The hip may be in fixed flexion or there may be pain on passive extension.
CT is performed for diagnosis. Treatment is with percutaneous CT-guided drainage and antibiotic therapy.

Other muscles marked in the image are depicted below.

questions.text: Based on the X-ray of the hand given below, what is the likely age of the person?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the appearance of pisiform(>10 years) but no fusion of base of 1st metacarpal(<17 years). Among the given options, the likely answer seems to be <17 years.

The base of all metacarpals appears at 2-3 years of age and fuse at 15-17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is <17 years. If it has fused the likely age is >15 years 

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age. Since it is present in this case, the age of the child is more than 10 years. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years.

Ossification Centres of Carpal Bones:

  • Capitate: 1-3 months
  • Hamate:  2-4 months
  • Triquetral: 2-3 years
  • Lunate: 3-4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4-6 years
  • Trapezium: 5-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 5-6 years
  • Pisiform: 10-12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18.

questions.text: The skull X-ray of a patient who presented with bone pains is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows cotton wool skull which is diagnostic of Paget’s disease.

Radiological features during the early phase of this disease include osteolytic (lucent) regions which is later followed by coarse trabeculae and bony enlargement. Sclerotic changes occur much later in the disease process. The lesions seen are:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion
  • Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull
  • Diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected
  • Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

The image below shows cotton wool appearance on skull X-ray:

The image given below shows the Tam O Shanter hat sign, with the hat it looks like:

questions.text: Identify the doppler image of the fetus given.
questions.solution:
The given image represents normal diastolic flow.

A: Normal diastolic flow 

B: Absence of end diastolic flow seen in IUGR

C: Reverse end diastolic flow seen in IUD

questions.text: A primigravida at 12 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of the expulsion of grape-like vesicles per vaginum for 1 day. She was diagnosed as a case of molar pregnancy on USG.  In addition, she has an adnexal lesion as given below.  What is the likely finding____
questions.solution:
The given USG image shows theca lutein cysts in the ovary. The ovaries contain multiple theca-lutein cysts in 25 to 60 percent of women with a complete mole.

They are usually bilateral and are also seen in multiple pregnancy. These likely result from the overstimulation of lutein elements by massive amounts of hCG. The contained fluid is rich in chorionic gonadotropin. It also contains estrogen and progesterone.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with feeding vessel as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Visualisation of a feeding vessel on colour doppler is characteristic of an endometrial polyp.

These are homogeneous, isoechoic lesions that are continuous with the endometrium and preserve the endomyometrial interface. They may be centrally cystic, corresponding to dilated fluid-filled glands.

Benign endometrial polyps may occur at all ages, with their greatest prevalence after age 50. They are a common cause of postmenopausal bleeding.

questions.text: The pelvic ultrasound of a 35-year-old woman is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the 'T-sign' seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy.

In monochorionic pregnancy, the chorion does not extend between the layers of the intertwin membrane. Thus, the inter-twin membrane comes to an abrupt halt in a T-configuration at the edge of the amniotic sac.

The image given below shows the T sign

In contrast, in a dichorionic pregnancy, the sonographic image depicts a  'twin-peak' sign or the 'lambda sign" as the Chorion is present between the intertwin membrane. A triangular portion of the placenta is seen inserted between the amniochorion layers.

The given ultrasound image shows the 'twin peak' sign. 

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance
Bagel sign
Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.
Ball Sign
X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.
Banana Sign
Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.
Double decidual sac Sign
Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.
Lambda Sign
The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.
‘T’ Sign
USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.
Bunch of grapes sign
USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.
Cloverleaf skull
Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: The full red arrow head in the below image represents _______
questions.solution:
The full red arrowhead represents the yolk sac. The empty red arrowhead shows the double ring: outer - decidua parietalis; inner decidua capsularis.

The sign is called double decidua sign, is seen in the first trimester transvaginal sonogram. It is useful to confirm an early intrauterine location for the pregnancy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is suffering from increasing difficulty in bending forward with increasing stiffness of the spine and reduced chest movements. A CT was performed and shown below, the likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The above scenario and the CT findings are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis (AS).

Diagnostic criteria for AS:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months  

Examination findings in AS:

  • Loss of lumbar lordosis
  • Increased thoracic kyphosis
  • Diminished spinal movements
  • Decreased chest expansion ( <7 cm)
  • Positive tests for sacroiliac joint involvement

Important X-ray features of AS:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign – erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later - peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest - flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later - ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels

The image below shows the bamboo spine appearance in AS.

Related Pearl: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

           DISH         AS
Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune
Age group Older patients (middle-aged) Younger patients
HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine" 
Disc space Preservation of disc space AS in cervical spine will show ossification of disc space 
SI joint involvement  No involvement (SI joint abnormality generally excludes the diagnosis of DISH)  Bilateral sacroiliitis
Associated disease Obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypervitaminosis A Autoimmune conditions like iritis, uveitis, ulcerative colitis

questions.text: A construction worker presented with pain and swelling of his right arm after falling on his side from a height. An upper arm X-ray was done which is given below. Which nerve is most likely to be injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the history and radiograph suggest a closed fracture of the shaft of the humerus. The radial nerve is commonly damaged in this condition.

It manifests as an inability to dorsiflex the wrist and digits (wrist drop and finger drop). Numbness occurs on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand and the dorsal aspect of the radial 3 1/2 digits. 

Management of humerus shaft fractures: 

  • Conservative management using a hanging cast or U-slab for 2-3 weeks followed by functional bracing
  • Surgical fixation by compression plating, interlocking intramedullary nail, semi-flexible pins, or an external fixator is indicated in:
    • Open fractures
    • Pathological fractures
    • Unstable humeral and forearm fractures (floating elbow)
    • Radial nerve palsy

The below X-ray shows shaft of humerus fracture.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the paediatrician with complaints of bilateral knee pain. His bone mineral density is normal.  The X-ray image of the joints is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the X-ray showing Pelkan spurs, Trummerfeld zone, and Frenkel's line are suggestive of scurvy.

Radiological findings in scurvy:

  • Frenkel's line - Zone of provisional calcification at the growing metaphysis is seen as a dense, white line called the Frankel's line.
  • Pelkan spurs - These are metaphyseal spurs formed due to fractures manifesting at the cortical margins. 
  • Wimberger’s ring sign - The sclerotic rim around the epiphysis forms this appearance.
  • Trummerfeld zone. - Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline in procollagen. There is the defective formation of connective tissue and collagen in the skin, bone, cartilage, dentine, and blood vessels which leads to their fragility.

Early manifestations include irritability, loss of appetite, musculoskeletal pain, and tenderness in the legs. Later on, the child can have swelling of the knees, ankles, and pseudo paralysis. Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and characteristic perifollicular haemorrhages.

Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle weakness. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary.

Other options:

Option C: Metaphyseal dysplasia: It is also known as Pyle's disease. There is a failure of remodelling the metaphysis. Erlenmeyer flask deformities of the distal femur and proximal tibia are seen in this condition. The patient can also develop genu valgum.

Option D: Pycnodysostosis: It is an autosomal recessive condition due to a mutation in the cathepsin K (CTSK) gene. It causes osteosclerosis and the affected individual has distinctive facial features and skeletal malformations. The patient has short stature and is prone to recurrent fractures due to their fragile bones. 

Related Pearl: Radiological features of scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. His heart rate was 100/min, respiratory rate was 24/min, and his chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is contraindicated in him?
questions.solution:
The given image shows elevation of left hemidiaphragm with bowel and stomach in place. The probable cause would be diaphragmatic hernia following blunt injury due to a road traffic accident. In this condition, chest tube insertion (option B) is contraindicated. 

Chest tube insertion/ thoracostomy is indicated in pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, pleural effusion, etc. Contraindications include pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.

A chest tube is inserted the in 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line in the triangle of safety. It lies

  • anterior to the midaxillary line
  • above the level of the nipple
  • below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle

 Nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, and epidural anesthesia are not contraindicated in an acquired diaphragmatic hernia.

Management: Blunt trauma to the diaphragm results in linear diaphragmatic rupture, which is usually large along with the herniation of the abdominal contents into the chest. Acute diaphragmatic injuries must be repaired via the abdominal approach, so that associated visceral injuries can also be managed.

Diaphragmatic edges are approximated with the help of Allis clamps, and the defect is closed with running a 1-0 polypropylene suture.

questions.text: A man presented with complaints of chest pain and a feeling of food getting stuck in the esophagus, after a meal. He has asthma and is under treatment. PPIs were prescribed but it did not resolve the problem so a barium swallow was done and showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and imaging findings are suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal one-third of the esophagus. There is migration of eosinophils to the esophagus and they contribute to extensive tissue damage and inflammation.  

Clinical features include swallowing difficulty, food impaction, vomiting, and heartburn.

Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus which is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis. These rings appear as stripes on the cat and is also known as the feline esophagus.

Feline esophagus:

The definitive diagnosis requires biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per high-power field.

Treatment includes oral corticosteroids and immunotherapy.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

 

The image below shows the lesions of CMV esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of candida esophagitis.

The image below shows feline esophagus in eosinophilic esophagitis.

The image below shows the erosive lesion of pill esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of HSV esophagitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was brought to the ER after RTA, his RR is 25/min, BP is 80/45mmHg. On examination, hyper-resonance is heard over the left side of the chest. The chest X-ray performed is given below. What would be the appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability, hyper resonance on the left side of the chest, and the X-ray are suggestive of tension pneumothorax. It is managed by inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS followed by placing an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS.

Traumatic pneumothorax can be:

  • Simple pneumothorax: Without hemodynamic instability
  • Tension pneumothorax: With hemodynamic instability

Management:

  • Simple pneumothorax: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Tension pneumothorax: 
    • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
    • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety

The X-ray given below is showing a left-sided tension pneumothorax. There is a large, well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side. The yellow arrows are pointing to the tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side. 

Note: According to ATLS 10th edition

  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, what is the finding shown in the image given?
questions.solution:
In a patient with abdominal pain with sterile pyuria, the given image finding points towards a diagnosis of a putty kidney. It is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB), specifically renal TB. The given image shows a homogenous and ground glass-like calcification of the kidney appearing like putty.

It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus is always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria. Diagnosis is confirmed with a tuberculin test, or at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine are examined for acid-fast bacilli. They are stained with a Ziehl–Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured.

CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB and its manifestations which are as follows:

  • Early: Papillary necrosis
  • Progressive:
    • Multifocal strictures
    • Generalized or focal hydronephrosis
    • Mural thickening and enhancement
    • Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma
  • End-stage:
    • Progressive hydronephrosis
    • Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney

Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery is often done.

Other options: Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules which is seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism. (option B)

Staghorn calculus is found in urinary infection with Proteus, Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus usually, and is not a cause for sterile pyuria. (Option C)

Psoas calcification is a muscle calcification and might be seen developing after acute renal failure and rhabdomyolysis. (Option D)

questions.text: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below.

choices.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
Micturating cystourethrography with prostratic urethra stricture

questions.solution:
The given image shows retrograde cystourethrogram with findings consistent with penile urethral stricture.

The male urethra can be visualized by retrograde urethrography (RGU) or voiding cystourethrogram (VCU), also known as micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities.

The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture:


In VCU, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra (membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is helpful for diagnosing posterior urethral abnormalities and bladder abnormalities. It is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.

The following image shows a voiding cystourethrogram in a patient with grade V VUR:

questions.text: All structures can be seen in the following x ray view except?
questions.solution:
The above X Ray view is called as ' Caldwell's view'.

Structures seen in Caldwell's view are:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

In Caldwell's view.

  • The nose and forehead are touching the x-ray film
  • The X-ray beam is projected 15 degrees h

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

questions.text: A patient presents to you with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis. Chest X-Ray shows the following finding. Which of the following is the method of protection of the lower airway that's compromised in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis and the X-ray showing dextrocardia (situs inversus) is suggestive of Kartagener syndrome. The mucociliary mechanism is compromised in this case, due to immotile cilia. 

The lower airway is protected by the following mechanisms:

  • Mucociliary mechanism - The inspired pathogens and dust are trapped on the viscous mucous blanket. By beating of the cilia, the mucus is carried to the nasopharynx to be swallowed. 
  • Chemical mechanisms - Immunoglobulins such as IgA, IgE, and Lactoferrin, lysozyme provide innate immunity.
  • Sneezing - It is a protective reflex due to irritation of the nasal mucosa.

Temperature regulation and humidification are due to the large surface area of mucosa and highly vascular cavernous spaces. This is achieved by an increase or decrease in blood flow which in turn increase or decrease the size of turbinates.
